Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 07:27AM GiGiL wrote: claireinaz, sometimes this type of procedure has to be done when the area of suspicion cannot be reached by other biopsy methods. I am sure part of the decision to do a more complete job was to save you having to have two procedures - one for diagnosis, and then possibly one for complete removal. I suspect there will be a pathologist nearby who will examine the tissue and guide the surgeon to get clear margins, or if it turns out to be a lymph node, they will decide where else to check. At times like this it is maybe better to have smaller breasts. Another thought, if it does turn out to be a lymph node, they would rather remove it, rather than disturb it. At any rate, xanax or a mild sedative during this time might allow you to rest when you need to.
Posts.Title: Still not diagnosed, but surgeon wants a lumpectomy claireinaz claireinaz

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 08:39PM GiGiL wrote: There are no statistics that I know of that also factor in diet and lifestyle changes and how much that improves one's odds in regard to developing a new tumor at some point.  Anyone know of a resource that would factor in diet, weight loss and improved exercise, as well as stress reduction?
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2013 08:10PM GiGiL wrote: Sciencegal and April I have been using turmeric also.  I put it in my smoothie in the morning.  I have read so much good research on it.  Besides cutting off the blood supply to any potential tumors, it really helps with inflammation.  I have had some pretty severe fibromyalgia and it has helped immensely.  I think it would definitely help.

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 08:36PM GiGiL wrote: Premenopausal with young children would be a big factor in deciding to do the chemo.  That would have made me lean toward it too.
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 09:06PM GiGiL wrote: I will definitely look for that book.  Thanks.  Since my diagnosis, I have done a ton of research and reading. I haven't found the book by Dr. Shervan, however.
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 07:47PM GiGiL wrote: BobbiMarie, my oncotype dx score came up on the high end of moderate risk.  I found my head spinning with statistics.  I did a ton of research online.  My estrogen and progesterone receptors were high.  I opted out of chemo after much thought and prayer.  The improvement in survival stats didn't seem worth the risks of chemo.  My MO told me that there were no wrong decisions in my case, and she would support me in whatever I decided to do.  I decided to go with radiation and hormone blocking therapy.  If my decision turns out to be in error in the future, I will not blame myself or anyone else.  I did my best to make the decision that was right for me.  Most physicians are worried about not doing the most they could do to prevent further problems.  Many cancer patients also want to err on the side of being too cautious.  Each person must make the decision that feels right to her.  if I remember correctly, your stats showed Progesterone negative receptors.  I would research that, and the effectiveness of drugs like Tamoxifen in that case.  That might help you decide which way to go.  Good luck.  It is not easy.  One would think there would be more firm answers, but alas until the TAILORx results come out, it is a bit of a crapshoot.
Posts.Title: Chemo - since I have a choice, why would I? BobbiMarie Lee7

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2011 09:01AM GiGiL wrote: LeeLee3 and LindaJanett, I told my son that I was going to be the kind of superhero who wears an age appropriate costume and goes around the world protecting kids.  He told me if I were to start to turn green or got really stretchy I might want to tell someone about it.  I replied that I was turning a little "pink" which is appropriate for the pink ribbon superhero, but that I wasn't glowing in the dark yet.   I had my freezer go out on Sunday and I very slowly and carefully pushed it across the floor using what I felt was my body, in order to check another grounded outlet.  I am now feeling some real muscle aches to the side of my radiated breast.  I am worried I might have taxed the muscle there, and the rads have put more stress on it.  Hopefully it will pass.  The pink that showed up on day 2 is now faded a bit and turned more tan.   I find the radiation treatments to be not unpleasant.  I don't like lying prone, and I have always used lots of pillows.   I have to be patient with lying prone and being shifted around on a sheet. The staff is very kind and we make it a point to  talk about day to day matters.  It helps to take the seriousness out of the situation.  And I keep repeating my mantra "God's healing hands on all healthy tissue".  There are light panels above me that look like trees with sunlight shining through.  One room has white blossoms and the other has pink.  I like the pink blossom room better, but they are both very pleasant. Love to all of you girls going through rads right now.  Today will be 7 down and 25 to go.  We can do this!!
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2011 01:07AM GiGiL wrote: I am joining the July group also.  I have my sim tomorrow morning.  Thank you GmaFoley for the information you so generously shared along your treatment path.  I am apprehensive, but eager to get this phase of treatment done.  I am not sure the length of the treatment regimen I will be following, but I know during the week, I will be ready to get this done.  I just had a call from the person who will be doing my CT scan and she told me it would only take a little while and there would be no contrast.  I am glad about that.  It has been difficult going from a person who enjoyed perfect health to a person who has been poked, prodded and scared the hell out of in the past few months.  I know you all know what I am talking about.  I am working on maintaining a positive attitude here, as that is the only way I can endure.  Thanks again to all of you who have been there, and are willing to share.
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

They said I will get the tat in the middle that day, and my full treatment schedule. Hope you all have a restful weekend.

I feel good about getting honest and sticking up for what I need right now. 11/33 for me today as well. I am fighting like a girl and kicking cancer's butt!
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2011 06:01PM GiGiL wrote: I hope everyone is having a nice radiation free weekend.  I finished 4/32 today.  I started getting pink after treatment number 2.  I have been alternating aloe with the cream the radiation tech gave me, four times a day, and an extra time of aloe if I should wake up during the night.  By morning the pink is much faded so far.  Thank you Gma Foley for your encouraging words.  It helped to hear that it doesn't have to get worse.  So far, no fatigue, but I realize it is early on.  I got three tattoos and it seems they decide to draw on one side each day with a Sharpee.  I think the tattoo is a bit light on that side.  I am glad to read that the time does go by quickly.  At the beginning, the length of time seemed so long.  I am getting used to the daily routine though, which always helps.  Bless all of us who are going through this together.  We can do it!
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2011 07:54PM GiGiL wrote: LeeLee congrats on finishing tomorrow.  I have 5 more regular full breast treatments and then 5 boosts.  The area where the tumor bed is is holding up well.  The outer edges and armpit are turning red.  When I get the boosts, will those areas start to heal?  What was your experience?  Elizabeth, it won't be long now for you.  Home stretch is in sight.  I am encouraged as each one of you comes to the end of the rads.  I know I will be about a week behind you Elizabeth.  Glad to hear more info about the boosts. Lena I think you are one day ahead of me.  How is your skin holding up?  I was only pink and then tan in one area since day two, and now the pink is spreading upward and into the armpit.  I had negative nodes, and still the armpit is getting blasted.  I didn't realize that until the redness has begun to appear.  I had been using the Tom's on the upper part until the end of last week.  Wish I would have known they were radiating that.  No one even mentioned the deodorant issue, although I had read it here on the board.
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2011 07:37PM GiGiL wrote: 5 treatments down, and 27 to go for me.  The weekend felt like such a relief.  Saturday the fatigue caught up with me.  My sister wanted to do something, so I put one foot in front of the other and met her for a movie and dinner.  My husband works weekends, and I am usually very alone with my thoughts.  It was nice to have my sis there.  We went out for brunch with a cousin on Sunday, and by the end of that, I was feeling energetic.  Good thing I had some energy, because I discovered early evening that our freezer had quit.  I had to empty the freezer and shuffle the frozen food around to preserve it.  I was glad to see my husband by the time he got home at midnight.  Today, I really felt like I had to gear up for treatment.  It did help to know what to expect and it is becoming a routine.  That helps some.  The therapists are always friendly and we find things to chat about during the preliminary set up.  It helps to relate to them on a personal level.  I haven't cried about radiation, but I have definitely had my fears.  My son suggested that I think of it as healing lasers, and he jokes that I am getting super powers because of the radiation.  It helps to joke about it, and I have used the idea of healing lasers to think of any errant cancer cells as being zapped out of existence.  I also pray for the hand of God to protect what needs to be protected as the treatments go on, and also to heal the healthy tissues in between.  I take a half a xanax now and then when the thoughts get to be too much.  I use visualization in the morning when I wake up too early and positive affirmations.  We can get through this girls.  We can do it!  We are getting stronger with every treatment.  We ARE getting super powers.  Much love to all of you.
Posts.Title: July 2011 rads Merilee jankc

J, you will get started again and maybe in the meantime your skin will get a rest.

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2011 09:09PM - edited Aug 7, 2011 09:14PM by GiGiL KateHudson the mapping or simulation was nothing near what I imagined it to be. I worried about the tiny tattoos they gave me, and they were painless. The rest of the process went quickly, and I was out of there in about 30 minutes. I laid on the table, they placed me in the right position with arms over the head. They inflated the pad under me and it became my mold. They did the two small tats on the sides, measured and marked the middle, put tape over that one, then they took me for the CAT scan which is done without contrast, so it is done with you lying on a table with a semi circular band going over you. Painless, and not tight or claustrophobic. Then it is finished. They did the middle tat after my first treatment. Again, just a small dot and painless. The treatments have been short and tolerable. The biggest part for me is the daily schedule and the driving. My skin turned a little pink the second day. Gma Foley from this board told me it wouldn't necessarily get worse, and so far so good. Her words were very welcome to me at first. Hope your experience goes smoothly. Take care and know the rads are tolerable.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2011 08:37PM - edited Aug 9, 2011 08:43PM by GiGiL Halfway through rads as of today.  LindaJanette, I have a meltdown at least once a week.  It just comes on without any warning, and suddenly everyone and everything is on my last nerve.  Last week my mother made the mistake of being hypercritical of my husband, and that set off a reaction from me that was completely unexpected.  After my diagnosis, I lost 19 lbs as well, but 5 have creeped back on.  I was so stressed out at first, and vowed never to eat anything that had been linked with breast cancer again!  I followed a pretty strict vegan diet for a couple of months.  Now, I am eating more chicken, fish and sometimes beef.  I cut dairy out completely, but have since let yogurt back into my life (thank goodness).  Yogurt is my mainstay when nothing else appeals to me.   Kshav congratulations on being finished.  I can't wait for that day to come.   Elizabeth1889 you are so right.  I am showing up every day, even though some days it is not so easy to do that.  Tonight having some digestive issues.  I am hoping it is related to the huge serving of cherries I ate before dinner and not to anything else.  I need to be in shape for tomorrow's treatment!

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2011 08:50PM - edited Aug 21, 2011 09:23PM by GiGiL Lena, you and I are very close in time for treatment.  I have had a rough weekend as well.  I have turned literally burgundy under my right arm, with lots of burning and discomfort.  I have olive skin, and I have noticed things getting worse as the weekend has gone on.  Before this,  the weekend gave enough reprieve that things began to improve.  I have used the cortisone cream over the weekend, the aloe and also the emu oil.  The cortisone cream may be the cause for the darkening color of the redness, or it may not be related.  I'm not sure.  I space my creams out over the course of the day.  It does seem the aloe has reduced the redness in small areas.  I used a dose of the cortisone cream at bedtime last night, and I swear it kept me half awake all night, and I had the most vivid dreams.  I am wondering since I am having to use it on such a large area, could I be experiencing some stimulation from it, the way oral cortisone works?  Dreading Monday this week, but trying to stay positive. LindaJanette, thank you for starting the new thread.  I will definitely go over there.  I am with you girls.  I need to take off 25 lbs., and not put any weight on!!

I think that will be a relief, in itself. One foot in front of the other to the end.

Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 10:08PM GiGiL wrote: I never took the pain meds.  I knew ahead of time that I wasn't going to be able to tolerate those.  Honestly, I think they make you feel worse than surgery does.  I had a pretty easy course of healing after surgery because I left those awful things alone.  Tylenol seemed to keep the pain dull and not too worrisome. I know exactly what you mean about coincidences.  When I was waiting to be diagnosed, I tried to take my mind off the subject of breast cancer.  I kept seeing things all around me, hearing things on the radio and having it come up in movies.  I wasn't allowed to forget about it, and I felt I was receiving a quiet message to be prepared for it.  I found it a bit distressing at the time.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 09:32PM GiGiL wrote: tjohnson, I had a lumpectomy the first part of July.  I have to tell you, I feared the preliminaries to the surgery and I can assure you the people who are there to take care of you will do it well, and spare the the pain.  I can honestly say I felt no pain at all.  I had never had surgery before, and I am 62 years old.  I had to have radioactive material injected before surgery.  It was done skillfully and painlessly.  I took a xanax the morning before also.  I was quite calm while I waited to go into surgery.  I was visited by my doctor and the anesthesiologist.  I was taken into surgery, gently put to sleep and the next thing I knew I was being talked to and told it was over and I could wake up.  I felt fine - almost euphoric.  I was asked what I would like to eat.  I chose ginger ale and soda crackers.  While I was eating that,  my husband and sister were allowed to come in.  I got up a bit later and went to the bathroom.  After that, I was allowed to get dressed, and was wheeled out to our car and dismissed.  I didn't have to take any pain medication or even a tylenol.  My surgeon had taped over the incision and I didn't realize until later that she had taken out a pretty large area around the tumor in order to obtain clean margins.  She also removed three lymph nodes under my arm.  I was up and on the internet quite late that first night and I slept very well.  I will never fear surgery again.  My diagnosis changed from Ia to IIa after the surgery because the tumor bed was larger than originally thought.  The lymph nodes were clear.  I, like you was very cranky before surgery and couldn't really talk to anyone who understood.  I think you are going through some very normal emotions.  Just allow yourself to be how you have to be right now.  You deserve some room to be able to process this.
Posts.Title: Did any of you get crabby or depressed before lumpectomy? tjohnson1971 Natters

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 10:29PM GiGiL wrote: Waiting is the worst.  I had to wait 48 hours for my results, and then I got them at the end of the day on a Friday.  I had the whole weekend to think aobut it and then saw my physician on Monday.  Waiting is absolute agony.  I can so relate.  I had to wait for the phone to ring both after the biopsy and then again after the surgery.
Posts.Title: Still Waiting AMP614 BeingHopeful1

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2011 08:41PM GiGiL wrote: So sorry to hear about your troubles.  Is there a womens' shelter where you can stay until you get on your feet?  Can you possibly apply for assistance in your state and get some help from social services?  It sounds like you are being abandoned by your family.  Your husband and then your daughter.  I don't know what family dynamics have gone on, so I can't comment on that.  All I know is that you need a place to stay, transportation and medical care.  Can social services help you?  Also can you find a support group where you can get some guidance and support and have someone to talk to?  I know this has to be very rough for you right now, and it is hard to know which way to turn.  Best wishes.
Posts.Title: BiRad 4 US need biopsy jobigsister TifJ

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2011 09:16PM - edited Sep 26, 2011 09:19PM by GiGiL Carole, I had an MRI.  I was terrified going into it.  It was really not bad at all.  I had an IV put in my hand, I laid on my stomach on a table that had an indentation for each breast.  They told me I had to lie still once they started.  There was a speaker in the half moon apparatus that went over the top half of my body.  It was open front and back.  The whole test took about 40 minutes.  The tech told me before each view.  I could hear rattling in the machine but felt nothing for the few minutes that each view took.  I just had to remember to lie still and be patient.  I kept repeating the mantra "healthy breasts, healthy breasts, healthy breasts" the whole time.  At one point the tech started putting contrast into the IV.  I felt a momentary coolness in the back of my hand and then the back of my neck.  That was it.  Just the rattling of the machine taking the views, soft music, a cool fan and the soothing voice of the tech.  When it was finished, she came and took out the I.V. and helped me roll over and sit up and slowly get to my feet.  I felt fine.  I had taken a low dose xanax beforehand, so I felt a little drowsy from that, but not a lot.  I sat outside in the sun with my husband afterward just to take a breather.  It is quite easy to tolerate.  The healthy breast mantra seemed to help.  My results only showed the tumor area as active.  I hope it all goes well for you.  Please, keep us posted.  I see this might have been written a little late to alleviate your fear.  How did your MRI go?
Posts.Title: Help, am scared about making wrong decision CaroleH CaroleH

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 12:07PM GiGiL wrote: Emerald good luck to you.  We are all pulling for a B9 result for you.  Reach out to support groups as much as you can in your area.  It sounds like you need a local support system.  These women here are wonderful as well, and it is so good to have their experience to draw from.  It really helped me when I was diagnosed.  You are a young woman with lots of years ahead of you.  Hopefully you can stay clear of those that are trying to force their relgious beliefs on you.  Moderation in all things, right?  The mammo followed by the ultrasound gives an indication there is something that looks like it needs to be biopsied.  The actual biopsy is the only way to tell for sure.  I had a core biopsy done with a biopsy gun.  It was painless, thanks to the astute administration of a local anesthetic.  I healed very quickly and well from it, and didn't have much pain at all.  The lumpectomy that followed was also tolerable.  Just take things one step at a time, and relax as much as you can.  Occupy your mind with whatever makes you feel good while you wait.  We are all here for you.
Posts.Title: Can doctors really see cancer on mammograms and ultrasound? Emerald097 dogeyed

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 01:23AM GiGiL wrote: My interventional radiologist used a small injection of lidocaine first.  I hardly felt that.  After that he did the radioactive injection.  It was almost completely pain free.  I was more worried about that part of it, than I was the lumpectomy surgery.  I worried for nothing.  When I woke up from surgery, I did have the most brilliantly blue breast I have ever seen.  My daughter took to calling me MaMa Smurf!  You've got to have a sense of humor.  Ten days after surgery, the blue is almost gone.  In time, it will be normal.
Posts.Title: Radioactive Injection into Nipple NOT TERRIBLE waynesgirl50 Motherofall6

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 12:37AM GiGiL wrote: MustangSally67, I know two women your age who have gone through bc.  Both because of the nature of their tumors had bilateral mastectomies with reconstruction.  One of the women has young children.  She is doing very well indeed, and the last I heard from her, she was having a wonderful summer with her kids, rock climbing and swimming and all kinds of fun.  I saw the other young woman yesterday, and her new reconstructed breasts look beautiful.  The good thing about being young is that you can endure treatment a bit better, in most cases, and healing comes faster.  I hope you can have some peace while you wait.  Waiting is the worst.  Once a plan is in place, you will feel better by increments.  Getting used to the idea is half the battle.  We as humans go into a state of shock at first, and slowly we find a way to accept what we need to, and we go on.  All my best to you,
Posts.Title: just diagnosed yesterday.... MustangSally67 Jen42

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 12:16AM GiGiL wrote: maggestatas, so sorry you are having to endure this.  The time between appointments and getting a plan in place seems to drag and the fear grows.  I was in your same shoes the Friday before Mother's Day.  You may be feeling like you can't endure this, but step by step and day by day you will get used to the idea.  Once you talk to a surgeon and get a plan in place, it will help.  Meanwhile, if you can, take solace in knowing how much better they are at diagnosing and treating breast cancer, and having breast cancer is not a death sentence.  Please keep us posted and come back just to vent in the meantime.  Sending you lots of positive energy and I'm hoping for peaceful moments for you until you can get things sorted out.
Posts.Title: Very confused and scared maggiestatas AnnieBear

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2011 12:18AM GiGiL wrote: Like HollyinMich, I took xanax for the MRI.  It just helps you to be able to lie still and relax until it is finished.  The thought of it and most things was much worse than the doing of it.   Many of us benefit from anti-anxiety medications.  It helps with the waiting and not knowing.
